thread.title: Australian dollar driven lower by Janet Yellen speech
thread.title_full: Australian dollar driven lower by Janet Yellen speech | afr.com

author: Share via Email
title: Australian dollar driven lower by Janet Yellen speech
text:
The Aussie had a choppy night but climbed over the key support level of US70c Phil Carrick Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Vanessa Desloires The Australian dollar fought back overnight, climbing back above the key US70¢ level, but struggled to hold as a speech by US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen put pressure back on the currency.
Just after 7.30am AEST the Aussie was buying US69.83¢. Before Ms Yellen's speech began at 7am it was fetching as high as US70.41¢.
Overnight it hit a low of US69.42¢ as global markets swung in a night of market turmoil.
In her speech Ms Yellen said despite opting to keep interest rates at near zero at the Fed's September meeting it was appropriate for the Fed to raise this year.
The Australian dollar swung upwards as the US dollar softened on weak US data Bloomberg "I anticipate that it will likely be appropriate to raise the target range for the federal funds rate sometime later this year and to continue boosting short-term rates at a gradual pace thereafter as the labor market improves further and inflation moves back to our 2 per cent objective," Ms Yellen said in a speech in Massachussetts on Friday morning Australian time.
That triggered a swift rise in the US dollar, sending the Australian dollar back below the key support level of US70¢.
Earlier gains in the Aussie came from weakness in the US dollar on soft economic data, Commonwealth Bank of Australia senior currency strategist Elias Haddad said.
"The USD eased during the overnight session following unimpressive US August durable goods orders and weaker US regional manufacturing surveys," he said.
 The added to the recovery in the Australian and New Zealand dollars, Mr Haddad said.
The weaker data would limit the upside in the US dollar, particularly against the yen and euro as expectations for a rate rise diminish.
"However, it also adds to global growth concerns which should further weigh on commodity sensitive (AUD, NZD, CAD) and emerging market currencies," Mr Haddad said.
The news of a fall in US business equipment for last month added weight to concerns that China's slowdown was having a bigger effect on the world's biggest economy.
The best overnight currency performer was the New Zealand dollar, National Australia Bank senior economist David de Garis said.
"Pre-Yellen, the best performer overnight was the NZD, up 1.22 per cent in the wake of yesterday's announcement from Fonterra increasing its payout, a hint to more confidence in the outlook for milk prices," he said.
"At the other end of the currency spectrum, the Norges Bank cut rates by 25 basis points to 0.75 per cent (the consensus expected no change), unseating the NOK [Norwegian krone]," he said.
